results.title: Sense and sensibility
results.creator_credit: Ang Lee, Lindsay Doran, Columbia Pictures and Mirage Enterprises
results.brief_description: Ang Lee directs this well scripted, acted and beautifully photographed version of Jane Austen’s first novel. Emma Thompson, (who wrote the screenplay), and Kate Winslet are Elinor and Marianne. Elinor uses her head and Marianne is guided by her heart. Both sisters eventually find love but only after the usual complications. A star-studded cast including Hugh Grant and Alan Rickman.

results.title: Saturday night: Sunday morning [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Rima Tamou, Pauline Clague, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, Australian Film Commission and New South Wales Film and Television Office
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Based on the Archie Weller short story, this film takes us on a journey into the discontented life of Melanie as she grapples with adolescence, rural isolation and life with her dysfunctional father. Her difficulties escalate when she is taken hostage by three young men for whom life has very little meaning and actions have no consequences. Essentially a rites of passage drama, both Melanie and her captors struggle to come to terms with assumptions of difference, indigenous and non-indigenous race relations, institutionalised injustice, and loss. Cast includes Alyssa McClelland, Peter Browne and Luke Caroll.

results.title: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.material_description: digital screen recording of @SenatorThorpe's Twitter, recorded with permission
results.brief_description: Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.
results.title_for_label: Senator Thorpe staunchly opposes fracking in the Beetaloo
results.description:
This video features in a responsive display in the museum that presents the moments, stories and memes capturing the zeitgeist by going viral on the internet.

Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.
description_for_label: Greens Senator Thorpe was kicked out of Parliament after revealing a BLM shirt during her speech opposing $50 million in federal funds be granted to frack NT’s Beetaloo Basin. Thorpe demanded both Labor and the opposition listen to the people instead of selling out to gas companies that endanger Aboriginal people and Country. Thorpe was ordered to leave for violating the dress code.

results.title: Windows
results.creator_credit: Gordon Willis, Mike Lobell and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This psycho-thriller with sexual overtones is the only directorial effort by acclaimed cinematographer Gordon Willis, who photographed many of Woody Allen’s films. Emily (Talia Shire) is a painfully introverted woman whose confidence has been further shattered by a rape attack. Her neighbour Andrea (Elizabeth Ashley), is a lesbian with a murderous past who harbours an obsessive attraction for Emily. With a highly homophobic script that provides no logic or motivation for the character’s actions, only the camerawork (by Willis) and score (by Ennio Morricone) redeem the film.

results.title: Harry's War
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Frankland, John Foss, ABC-TV (Australia), Film Victoria, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service, AFI [au] and Golden Seahorse Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Crossing Tracks Series”.
Harry, a Koorie, and Mitch, a non-Aboriginal Australian, are two mates who go off to fight in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War. Harry grows from a boy in uniform to a man in war. We watch as he learns of his impending death and how he faces it. ‘Harry’s War’ is about when mateship transcends race, cultural differences and social barriers. It is a story of how war drives men to the brink and the journey becomes more important than the journey’s end. Cast includes: David Ngoombujarra, Peter Docker, Glenn Shea, Bob Maza and Christina Saunders.

results.title: Windhorse
results.creator_credit: Thupten Tsering, Paul Wagner, Julia Elliott and Paul Wagner Productions
results.brief_description: Director Paul Wagner along with his cast and crew posed as tourists with video cameras to shoot this film on location in Tibet, avoiding Chinese secret police and security cameras in the process. The film follows a number of story lines that depict the plight of Tibetans at the hand of Chinese aggressors. Cast includes Dadon, Jampa Kelsang, Richard Chang, Lu Yu and Taije Silverman. Many cast and crew have asked that their names be withheld to protect themselves and their families. In Tibetan and Chinese with English subtitles.

results.title: Willy Wonka and the chocolate factory [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Mel Stuart, David L. Wolper, Stan Margulies, Quaker Oats Company and Wolper Productions
results.brief_description: This funny and inventive screenplay by Roald Dahl is based upon his best-seller “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory.” Gene Wilder is at his zany best as Willy Wonka, owner of a world-famous sweet factory who offers the fabulous prize of a tour of his extraordinary premises to five lucky children. However, when the winners arrive to claim their reward, they are caught up in a series of incredible and exciting adventures as Willy Wonka tests their honesty. The Academy Award nominated soundtrack includes the hit “Candy Man”.

results.title: TV miniatures
results.credit_line:
Designed by Graham McGuffie
Emily Boutard and Megafun
results.brief_description: These six miniature dioramas reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.

constellations_primary.name: Nightly news and laughs
constellations_primary.description: Throughout the decades on Australian screens, comedy and news have often gone hand-in-hand.

results.description: Television didn’t just change the way we see the world; it changed the look and layout of our homes. Since TV arrived in Australia in the 1950s, how and where we watch TV evolved alongside its form and function. These six miniature dioramas, designed by Graham McGuffie and handmade by Emily Boutard, reflect how home interiors changed to make way for TV across different decades, representing the common places people watched their favourite stories unfold on-screen.
